results.title: Janelle James Loves Being a Bad Boss in ‘Abbott Elementary’
results.abstract: The comedian talks about her breakout acting role as a hilariously terrible elementary school principal in the hit ABC sitcom.

results.title: After Upheaval, MOCA Bets on Johanna Burton to Bring Stability
results.abstract: She is the fifth person since 2008 to lead the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, an important institution that has faced a great deal of turmoil.
results.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Robin Pogrebin
org_facet: Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art

multimedia.caption: Johanna Burton said that “really prioritizing stability” at MOCA was at the top of her agenda.
multimedia.copyright: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

results.title: New York Lets ‘Fearless Girl’ Hold Her Ground, for Now
results.abstract: Officials voted to extend the sculpture’s permit but is requiring stakeholders to return in six months with plans for a permanent location.

multimedia.caption: After “Fearless Girl” moved to the steps of the New York Stock Exchange, thousands continued to gather each year for a selfie with the girl holding her ground.

results.title: Broadway Bets Big on a Spring Rebound. Will the Virus Cooperate?
results.abstract: It will be the busiest April for Broadway openings in more than a decade. But some of its biggest stars have been sidelined by positive tests.

multimedia.caption: Matthew Broderick and Sarah Jessica Parker celebrated the long-delayed opening of “Plaza Suite,” the comedy in which they are co-starring. A little more than a week later, they both tested positive for the coronavirus.
multimedia.copyright: OK McCausland for The New York Times

results.title: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard to Face Off in Defamation Trial
results.abstract: Mr. Depp sued his ex-wife, Ms. Heard, for an op-ed she wrote in The Washington Post referring to herself as a “public figure representing domestic abuse.”

multimedia.caption: Johnny Depp’s lawsuit, which accuses his ex-wife, Amber Heard, of defaming him in a Washington Post op-ed, goes to trial on Monday.

results.title: Review: The Choreographer Kyle Marshall’s Spacious Slow Burns
results.abstract: Marshall’s solo “I & I,” set to reggae, was the highlight of his company’s program at the Chelsea Factory.

results.title: Benedict Lombe Wins the Blackburn Prize for ‘Lava’
results.abstract: The British Congolese playwright earned the $25,000 prize for her memoir-monologue that deals with Black identity and displacement.

multimedia.caption: The playwright Benedict Lombe has won the Blackburn prize for “Lava.”
The playwright Benedict Lombe has won the Blackburn prize for “Lava.”

results.title: Red Hot Chili Peppers Top Chart With ‘Unlimited Love’
results.abstract: The band reunites with its former guitarist, John Frusciante, and the producer Rick Rubin for its latest album.

multimedia.caption: The Chili Peppers, performing on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon.” “Unlimited Love” had the equivalent of 97,500 sales in the United States, according to the tracking service Luminate, formerly known as MRC Data.

results.title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The First Lady’ and ‘Abbott Elementary’
results.abstract: Viola Davis, Michelle Pfeiffer and Gillian Anderson star in a new series about first ladies in the White House. And “Abbott Elementary” airs its season finale.

results.title: Tove Ditlevsen’s Fiction Is Bleak and Claustrophobic — Mostly in a Good Way
results.abstract: In “The Trouble With Happiness” and “The Faces,” the Danish writer who found posthumous English-language fame with “The Copenhagen Trilogy” writes about women who struggle and settle.

results.title: The Shakespearean Tall Tale That Shaped How We See Starlings
results.abstract: Researchers debunked a long-repeated yarn that the common birds owe their North American beginnings to a 19th-century lover of the Bard. Maybe this ubiquitous bird’s story is ready for a reboot.

multimedia.caption: A pair of European starlings nesting in the cavity of a tree near Heckscher Playground in Central Park.

results.title: ‘Billions’ Season 6 Finale Recap: Rhoades to Perdition
results.abstract: Two men sit in a prosecutor’s office. One will go to jail. Things are about to get complicated.

multimedia.caption: Prince and Chuck, (Corey Stoll, left, and Paul Giamatti) embarking on a very expensive expensive game of chicken.

results.title: ‘Birthday Candles’ Review: Another Year, Another Cake, Another Profundity
results.abstract: Debra Messing expounds on the preciousness of life in a production that aspires to convey eloquent whimsy, but too often feels methodically sentimental.

multimedia.caption: Matt (John Earl Jelks) and Ernestine (Debra Messing) in Noah Haidle’s “Birthday Candles.” With a fanciful offstage chime, Ernestine instantly skips from one age to the next.

results.title: Jordan Mooney, an Avatar of Punk Style, Dies at 66
results.abstract: Swathed in rubber and glowering from spiked heels, she was a fearsome figurehead for a generation of disaffected English teenagers.

multimedia.caption: Jordan Mooney on King’s Road, in front of the store where she became famous. She became the living embodiment of the store, and also its gatekeeper, embracing its anarchic ethos.
Jordan Mooney on King’s Road, in front of the store where she became famous. She became the living embodiment of the store, and also its gatekeeper, embracing its anarchic ethos.
Jordan Mooney on King’s Road, in front of the store where she became famous. She became the living embodiment of the store, and also its gatekeeper, embracing its anarchic ethos.

results.title: ‘Cabaret,’ Starring Eddie Redmayne, Sweeps Olivier Awards
results.abstract: The musical won seven awards at Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys. A puppet-filled adaptation of “Life of Pi” and a “Back to the Future” musical also won big.
des_facet: Back to The Future: The Musical (Play)

multimedia.caption: Eddie Redmayne and Jessie Buckley in “Cabaret,” which collected seven awards on Sunday.

results.title: Review: Dance Theater of Harlem’s Soulful Ballet to Stevie Wonder
results.abstract: Robert Garland’s “Higher Ground” combines classical ballet and vernacular Black dance to sharpen the social commentary in Wonder songs from the ’70s.

multimedia.caption: From left, Alexandra Hutchinson, Amanda Smith, Anthony Santos, Kouadio Davis, Daphne Lee and Micah Bullard in Robert Garland’s “Higher Ground,” to 1970s-era Stevie Wonder.

results.title: Dylan McDermott Wants to Be a Good Guy for a Change
results.abstract: After spending the past several years playing pimps and crime bosses, the actor is trying on heroism in “FBI: Most Wanted.”

multimedia.caption: “FBI: Most Wanted” offers Dylan McDermott his first leading role in awhile. “They’re frankly not giving many shows to a 60-year-old guy,” he said.

results.title: One Opera, Three Acts, Three Different Stagings
results.abstract: In Stuttgart, Wagner’s “Die Walküre” is being divided among a trio of creative teams with divergent visions.

multimedia.caption: The Valkyrie sisters in Act III of Stuttgart’s “Die Walküre,” directed by the artist Ulla von Brandenburg, known for using bright textiles in her videos and installations.

results.title: Molly Shannon’s Memoir Is Filled With Mischief and Pathos
results.abstract: “Hello, Molly!,” the former “Saturday Night Live” star’s new book, recounts early family tragedy and a career of transgressive humor.

results.title: Eleanor Munro, Who Profiled Women Artists, Is Dead at 94
results.abstract: Her 1979 book featured interviews with dozens of artists, but she also wrote on other subjects — pilgrimages, for instance.
des_facet: On Glory Roads: A Pilgrim's Book About Pilgrimage (Book)

multimedia.caption: Eleanor Munro in an undated photo. “In a way,” she said, her 1979 book about women artists “was an autobiographical search for myself.”

results.title: Delia Ephron Writes Her Way Through Cancer to a Happy Ending

results.title: Will Smith Barred From Attending Oscars for 10 Years After Slap
results.abstract: Smith, who won best actor this year, can still be nominated for Oscars, industry officials said, but will be unable to attend the Academy Awards ceremony and other events.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Will Smith struck the comedian Chris Rock at the Academy Awards after taking offense at a joke, stunning viewers and overshadowing the awards ceremony.

results.title: Outspoken Composer to Lead International Contemporary Ensemble
results.abstract: George E. Lewis, a Columbia scholar who has documented how Black composers have been excluded from experimental music, will lead the renowned group.

results.title: Rae Allen, Tony Winner and TV Mainstay, Dies at 95
results.abstract: In a varied career, she had memorable roles in “Damn Yankees” and on “Seinfeld” and was nominated for three Tonys. She later became a director.

multimedia.caption: Rae Allen with Ray Walston in the 1955 Broadway musical “Damn Yankees.” She stopped the show with her rendition of the jaunty “Shoeless Joe From Hannibal, Mo.”
multimedia.copyright: Billy Rose Theater Division, the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts

results.title: Officials Say Russian Art, Seized by Finns, Should Return Home
results.abstract: Finnish custom officials had seized the art several days ago, but the Finns and European Union officials decided that art lent to museums for exhibit did not come under sanctions.

multimedia.caption: Crates of art from Russian museums that were seized by Finnish customs officials. Officials later decided the art, which had been on loan to institutions in the West, was not subject to sanctions.
Crates of art from Russian museums that were seized by Finnish customs officials. Officials later decided the art, which had been on loan to institutions in the West, was not subject to sanctions.
